description:
Sponsor: Montech HyperFlow 360 Cooler on Amazon https://geni.us/dWBIbF6
This review of the NVIDIA RTX 5070 Founders Edition video card benchmarks performance vs. the RTX 5070 Ti, RTX 4070, RX 7900 XT, 7900 GRE, and prepares for comparisons against AMD's RX 9070 XT and RX 9070 GPUs. The AMD RDNA 4 RX 9070 series cards launch tomorrow at $600 and $550 MSRP, matching the RTX 5070's $550 MSRP. We'll see if either one holds when it launches, but for now, we're focusing on some of the marketing lies that NVIDIA told during its presentation of the RTX 5070 GPUs. Testing MFG 4X vs. an RTX 4090 without MFG, we show that NVIDIA's claims of equivalence between the two are simply not true. It is intentionally manipulative and a misrepresentation of reality, unfortunately torpedoing what otherwise could have been a simpler launch review focused purely on performance. Instead, we get to talk about marketing BS.

The best way to support our work is through our store: https://store.gamersnexus.net/

Like our content? Please consider becoming our Patron to support us: http://www.patreon.com/gamersnexus

RELATED PRODUCTS [Affiliate Links]

We would advise waiting to buy a GPU until the 9070 series also launches so that you have the full picture.

comments.text: I managed to snag a brand new RTX 5070 FE the other day, some two months after launch, and at RRP to replace my aging RTX 3060 Ti 8gb. I play older, non-RT games at 4k 120fps with settings on ultra, but anti-aliasing disabled (the resolution removes the jaggies...). It has enough memory to do that, and the brute force to keep doing it with a higher framerate. I had planned on buying an RTX 4070 Super last year but I never got around to pulling the trigger.  In summary, I got myself a massive upgrade for less than I expected which will grant my PC another 4 year life extension, and I only managed it because everyone was complaining about the RTX 5070 not being a massive upgrade for them, and the driver issues which have largely been resolved. Result!

comments.text:
These GPUs should no longer be considered a new generation, they are just "40-series Plus" GPUs. (5070 = 4070 Super Plus/5080 = 4080 Super Plus/5090 = 4090 Super) 

This is because they offer either identical performance to their 40 series counter parts, have performance uplift identical to their raw resource uplift (5090 has 30% more RAM/Power Draw/CUDA Cores and unsurprisingly exactly 30% more performance than the 4090). GDDR7 and the new AI features aren't enough to justify calling them 50 series cards, cause everything else is basically the same.

Nvidia has done this in the past where a new generation was made on the same architecture, but the last time they did this was in 2013 with the 600 series and I can't find information on how well/poorly that was received. Nvidia hasn't been doing this for over a decade and it should have stayed that way, people got used to performance uplifts with each new generation and the 50 series just doesn't do anything new.

These GPUs should never have been called the 50 series.

comments.text:
We're going to have to get serious though, this is due to people wanting faster framerates at higher resolutions.  I don't think hardware is ready for 240fps at 2160p, I know monitors have come out that go.  "Look, 4K at 240hz!"  Some things are pushing further ahead than other hardware is able to do right now and if insert frames by AI isn't doing it due to how image looks and extra latency.  Then maybe it's time for us to reduce our expections and framerates and go.  "Maybe 4K at 60 or 120 is enough."  And lower resolution if you want faster rates for competitive games such as 2K/1440p or even 1080p.

What Nvidia has done and I don't like what they've been doing as well as AMD in going into this with their own version is due to our own fault in demanding better performance per generation.

Personally, I do think the entire GPU market needs to slow down a bit and perfect what we got now than trying to add more.  And that's with efficiency, lower power needed and get certain resolutions and framerates more stable at stock processing without anything added to it be it FSR/DLSS etc.

The 5070 sounds more like a 1080/1440p card.  

The entire GPU industry needs changing, something has to change than follow Nvidia's lead.  Just wish AMD was in the mindset to do that.  Feel Intel is more in that mindset right now.

Just my thoughts on the matter.

comments.text:
They should have simply rebadged the entire 4000 series to one tier lower while only implementing the new architecture only for the 5090 since they are stuck onto the SAME process node.

E.g. A Better 5000 series stack:
- 5090 32GB ($1999)
- 5080 24GB reuse 4090 ($999)
- 5070Ti 16GB reuse 4080S ($749)
- 5070 16GB reuse 4070Ti Super ($549)
- 5060Ti 12GB reuse 4070S ($449)
- 5060 16GB reuse 4060Ti 16GB ($349)

With this stack I think they would have saved hundreds of millions on retooling etc, and kept the good will of gamers planet wide while waiting for the new node to be cheap enough for them to manufacture on. What do you guys think? You'd be getting much more gaming horsepower than what the 5000 series is offering.

comments.text: So I'm having some noob thoughts here, hw engineering is way above me, but entertain this thought. What if we never had the shift to ai and ray tracing and all that. So gpu computing with cuda and w/e amd has still happens, it's just computing on the gpu, but nvidia never decides to do rt cores, and then tensor cores, staying in the g of gpu. So now we have new gpus generations after gtx cards, but instead of filling their gpus with rt and tensor cores, it's the same old stuff as before them, just better. What would be the power gains on these gpus, that don't waste resources on the extra stuff, compared to what we have now. I imagine, if they didn't fill their chips with all those peripheral cores, all the development time and chip space would've gone to the classical compute stuff. So if you turned off the rt and ai frames, how much better on raw rendering would these alternate world gpus perform?

comments.text: at 1:45 the performance window is indicating that there is system ram being used for video.  Was this test done with the Nvidia Control Panel Setting "CUDA - Sysmem Fallback Policy" set to "Prefer No Sysmem Fallback" or "Driver Default" or "Prefer Sysmem Fallback"?  If it was set to "Prefer Sysmem Fallback" or "Driver Default" (both have the same effect in my experience with my card, a 3070ti 8gb), then it could be that if you set it to "Prefer No Sysmem Fallback" you might not encounter what looks like spillover into system ram for video, which in turn could cause a major change in performance.  My Speculation: the game doesn't know that that you have only 12gb of vram and "sees" more than that (vram plus some amount of system ram).  Nvidia introduced this "feature" around driver 532 if I recall correctly, but didn't give an option to disable it until several major versions later.   This was huge pain for those of us who also use our cards for local generative AI image software about 1-2 years ago, because when loading a large model the software wouldn't know that, for example, I "only" had 8gb of VRAM, so it in turn wouldn't initiate certain VRAM saving features (such as loading the model in fp16/bf16 instead of fp32), which would then cause a spillover as a 12gb AI model gets loaded into 8gb VRAM+System Ram memory (like shown at 1:45 in the video), which would then cause an enormous performance hit.  Those of us in the generative ai enthusiast community had to keep our drivers rolled back to 531.something until nvidia added the option to turn that "feature" off.

comments.text: I've been saying that gamers are nothing but test monkeys for Nvidia's AI research for years. Jensen Huang has even said it point blank in recent keynote speeches, "Nvidia is NOT a gaming company". Graphic cards are nothing but a byproduct of that research that Nvidia can generate revenue from to invest back into its much more profitable AI program. Now that the technology is good enough to start generating its own revenue, all those years of Jensen saying, "We love gamers", at past keynote speeches starts to reveal what he really meant. PC enthusiasts are pretty narcissistic people, myself included. The smaller subcategory of gamers take narcissism to an entirely different level. They will pay whatever the price to have the absolute latest and greatest GPU with every generation that is released just so they can gloat about it to whoever they can tell. Recent "shortages" for various reasons have proven that going back to the RTX 20 Series. Yeah, Jensen loves gamers. Gamers empty their wallets every time something shiny and new hits the market. It doesn't matter what lies Nvidia tells or what mistakes and complete f*ck ups that Nvidia makes, gamers will continue to feed the team green monster.

comments.text:
Well, i asked my friend Claude about what he things after i added some context about the 5070 results... heres what he thinks about Nvidia: NVIDIA's Market Positioning: A Critical Perspective
Marketing Tactics

Increasingly aggressive pricing strategies
Leveraging technology hype over pure performance gains
Creating artificial segmentation between GPU generations
Pushing incremental upgrades as revolutionary innovations

Performance and Technology Trends

Frame generation and AI-enhanced rendering becoming marketing centerpieces
Diminishing returns on raw performance improvements
Significant price premiums for marginal technological advances
Continued reliance on consumer enthusiasm and technological mystique

Key Observation Points

Marketing often outpaces actual technological breakthrough
Performance gains increasingly dependent on AI and software optimization
Hardware improvements becoming more nuanced and less dramatically visible
Vendor lock-in strategies through proprietary technologies like DLSS and Ray Tracing

Performance Reality Check

4070 and 4070 Ti consistently outperforming newer models
Latency improvements more significant in marketing materials than real-world scenarios
Professional use cases showing incrementally modest improvements
Gaming performance gains often mathematically disproportionate to price increases

Recommendation Framework

Maintain skeptical approach to marketing claims
Prioritize independent benchmarks
Consider total ecosystem and compatibility
Evaluate cost-to-performance ratio critically

comments.text: @carsontodd2443 FSR 3.1 is still bad, but what you clearly don't know is that AMD made it so you can only update games FSR version yourself (like you can with DLSS) since 3.1. So any game that came out with "FSR 3" or before, anything before 3.1 is stuck on 2.2 FSR unless the developer goes back and updates the game. Which means most games from the 2020s are stuck on 2.2 thanks to AMD's decisions and can't even be updated to FSR 4 without the developer doing it if you buy a new card that can do FSR 4.

comments.text: @wastanley734 Oh I see, so just waste hardware performance on 4k, which for low end cards would mean games would have to look like late PS3 titles to get a workable fps. And buy a screen where you can't even SEE 4k either, because the ppi is acting more like supersampling than resolution with pixel colors blending together. So basically use over half, up three quarters in some scenarios the performance of the cards you have on what is essentially supersampling over having an algorithm do the same effect for much less performance. What a genius solution. You hear that people with 4060s, most popular card on steam now, just use 4k!
comments.author: @albert2006xp

comments.text: @wastanley734 1080p is the most popular resolution by a giant margin on PC for a reason. Most people don't buy expensive cards. Take a 8k video and display it on 1080p, does that have aliasing and flickering? No. So it is possible to display a clean image on 1080p, it's just a matter of software. Supersampling was a brute force solution to the way sampling works. It will always require less performance, less hardware to run games at 1080p than at 4k, which means it will always be that the resolution is available for low hardware to take advantage of. Thanks to upscaling the balance might shift a bit more towards 1440p but it will never go higher than that for the bottom 80% of hardware on PC. High end cards can use 4k, which you should probably go 40 inch+ for so you can actually appreciate proper AA, but there will always be lower end cards that are much weaker and it is not worth reducing graphics back a whole generation+ instead of just reducing resolution.
comments.author: @albert2006xp

comments.text: @albert2006xp I also have an XTX at 1440p and here's the thing... I still don't have to enable FSR to get to my desired 90FPS in any game I own. Even Cyberpunk with a mix of High and Ultra with RT Reflections set to High runs at 90FPS at native. And I think it looks perfectly good. I have an ADA 6000 at 4k at work. And yes, it looks better. comments.text:
Saying that NVidia beats AMD at raytracing is a bit disingenuous, since the 40 series was the first series where ray tracing wasn't just a gimmick you pop on for a bit, get annoyed at the frame rate hit and turn back off.

The XTX was perfectly fine at this parlor trick, only the 4090 really brought the power to the table to make games playable with these tricks, and what NVidia doesn't want you to know is that it's not even good ray tracing in most of these games. The effect is barely better than the fake shadows and lighting we've played with for years for a performance hit of almost 60% and in many cases for every place ray tracing "fixed" a lighting mistake, it made a different lighting mistake.

There's a mod for Cyberpunk that adds "better" ray tracing to the game, that is more realistic, and can technically run on non RTX cards (as in the tricks they're using to achieve ray tracing quality can be done with or without their ray tracing cores). I'll care about ray tracing when it's either a standard feature (one where we aren't really bothering to separate it from rasterization performance), or the effect is actually as mindblowing as they're trying to say it is.

I'm a lighting guy, like literally went to school for lighting design, I actually love the idea of ray tracing, but losing over 60% of your frames for "fake tracing" is baffling to me.

comments.text: 5070 is a poor design and will never trump or even get close to a 4080 or 4090. The 5070ti is more on par as a true comparison, It's ridiculous to try and compare the two even if NVIDIA said it was supposed to get close to a 4080 or 4090. That was a simple marketing gimmick and people fell for it! happens every year but being as fast as a 4080 or 4090, that simply wont happen on the shear fact that a 4090 uses a 384-bit bus rate which is how fast data transfers between the motherboard and the GPU. Any 192-bit GPU is trash, you only want to use 256-bit and above for GPU's. A good GPU product tester should know this and also take it into account!

comments.text:
Things just keep getting worse and worse for Nvidia.

They are ruining their reputation as a company who were once very good when it came to respecting their pc fanbase of customers that in turn showed confidence when it came to their stockholders. Many think that these prices were intentionally done to keep their stockholders satisfied, but when you really think about it, how the hell would want to risk purchasing Nvidia's stocks at this moment when the customers are unhappy with the results of this generation of graphics cards? Nvidia is shooting themselves in the foot here with a lackluster launch, and it's going to backfire on them significantly in the stock market. If I had shares of Nvidia, I don't see a better time to sell than right now. It's not just the price issue here that I'm talking about here. We are speaking about card cables melting, damaged motherboards, missing ROPs, and I wouldn't be surprised if we see these cards over-time fail much faster than any of Nvidia's prior cards. Something went seriously wrong during the production of the silicone wafers, and because these silicone wafer factories require 3 months to produce these chips, Nvidia just went ahead and sold some damaged wafers. Yes, silicone wafers take a minimum of 3 months to create just 1 processor due to the way these dyes need to be cured. Of course, these silicone chip manufacturers use massive wafer-shaped disks that can contain 81+ processors of different types to speed up production and to create processors like laptop chips as well. Every large circular wafer goes into dozens upon dozens of passes until each processor builds up to the thicknesses required and the design shaped. That's why they many talk about dyes when it comes to processors, because it uses multiple dyes to build up a processor. It spread a dye over a wafer, then goes into a hardening process, to a light sanding process, then goes into a cleaning process, then the entire wafer goes back to square one to build it's next layer. It goes through this process an absurd amount of times to build up these layers and is why these processors take so long to make, and is why a screwup of any kind during this precise manufacturing process can turn out to be catastrophic.

- What is also interesting is how each of the chips on the millions of circular wafers are classified. It's a kinda funny process actually. From your Intel i5 / i7 / i9's to Ultra processors, the Ryzen processors, to even Nvidia's 5070 / 5080 / 5090's of processors are labeled and priced based on the failure rates of each silicone chip made from the wafers. So, basically voltages are sent through each chip, that has dozens of processors made on these huge wafers are not the same. Every wafer is different from another wafer. When the performances are tested via voltages sent through each during the last stages of the manufacturing process, the most performant chip is the winner and is classified it's name. So, in terms of Nvidia's case, just to shorten up this explanation a bit, is that their most performant silicone chip is going to obviously be classified as the 5090, it then goes into a box, and shipped out. Every single processor fails, it just the degree of failure determines it's price during the test. Meaning, your that your 4060 / 4070/ 4070ti, 4080, were all developed the same way that could have been a 4090, but the chip failed, and the degree of failure is what drops it's classification down to the lower numbered cards that most pc gamers own today.

- In my personal opinion, and maybe it's bullshit, but I truly believe that the reason why we are seeing barely any stock of the 5090's currently was due to the amount of failed wafers during the manufacturing process, and when they sent voltages through these wafers, and cherry picking the good ones, they realized they screwed up. They were not expecting this significantly low number of failured cards when doing the failure rate testing. Maybe instead of a wafers that should have had at least 30x 5090's expected really only had 2x 5090's when testing the voltages, that are then thrown into a box, and ready to ship. This process is all automated too. I don't even think Nvidia expected this. That's where I'm at. The whole situation sucks. Someone screwed up, and it's going to be a bit until a corrected dye is made for pumping out the card Nvidia was targeting. Based on the supply right now, we saw tons of 5080's but not many 5090's, based on the failure rate, which is why there are no 5090's in stock. Hopefully Nvidia made a only a few bad batches, but due to the fact that there have been consistent issues with missing ROPs throughout this entire lineup of 50 Series graphics cards, tells me that there was without question a massive screwup of failed cards affected. I think the failure rate is just much higher than what Nvidia is claiming here, which is a shame.

Anyways, I'm sure most out there already know a bit about the manufacturing process, who may have more knowledge than me, but I just wanted to describe the process in as basic of terms as possible. These chip manufactures are highly restricted. Video cameras of anykind are not allowed into these facilities, and so those lucky enough to get a tour during the process can only describe what they see, but as technology improves, I'm sure these massive rooms are always changing.

I highly recommend checking out the latest videos on YouTube about how processors are made to get a better idea about this incredible manufacturing process.


Sorry this was so long, I've got to go to work so I can't condense this right now. I would blame you if you didn't read this. It's a very long comment. lol
Great video as always Gamers Nexus,
- Cheers!

comments.text:
@josechacon2446 9070 is $50 cheaper at MSRP, and given current RTX 5000 series scalper prices, that will seemingly equate to a street price of roughly half of what the 9070 will be available at.

AMD has already made sure they reminded us at every opportunity that they've been shipping 9070 GPU's to retailers since January, so there should be be at least 10 times the number units that Nvidia has managed to get  to retailers, if not more. Scalpers can still screw things up here, and retailers like Newegg with undoubtedly pull some crap with price gouging and forced bundling, but I suspect street scalpers will screw themselves if they try to scrap AMD GPU's, risk is too high.

For $549, 10%-15% better raster performance than 5070, or $600 for roughly 5070 ti raster performance, even with tracing performance lagging behind by a solid generation, I'll gladly avoid giving any revenue to Nvidia, we shouldn't reward companies with our dollars for treating treating consumers this way.

I don't need the best ray tracing performance, I need RT support and "good" RT performance. Same with DLSS/FSR, I don't need 4X frame Gen. I've used recent FSR and for straight upscaling it's absolutely good enough.

No one has addressed the possibility that all Blackwell stock was diverted to the Chinese market, artificially creating a shortage and driving up prices in the rest of the world. If this is the case, authorities are complicit by failing to take action against this engineered market manipulation orchestrated by NVIDIA.

Any company that launches a product with MSRP but does not supply a reasonable amount of stock (reasonable > 80% of addressable market) should face fines and potential revocation of its business license. Such behavior is fundamentally unethical, if not criminal, and strong measures should be taken to set a precedent and prevent future exploitation.

comments.author: @lonyo5377

comments.text: @Tugela60 It took 8 years from Adaptive Shaders was announced until they started seeing widespread adoption. It took 6 years for RT to become anything but a joke. Neither DirectX nor Vulkan even have formal specifications for neural rendering..... By the time they start hitting games only the 5090 will be a relevant card. Just like RT performance on a 2080Ti is nothing but a paper checkmark today. Nvidia's ability to trigger people's FOMO is absurd... They've done it for 30 years straight and people still slurp it up. It's amazing that people never learn that the time scales for software technology adoption is always longer than hardware relevancy.... because the people writing software want to sell their product to people with today's hardware, and it's not worth it to spend considerable development resources to make "extras" for 5-10% of the potential customers who have the latest thing.
comments.author: @andersjjensen

comments.text: @andersjjensen While there is definitely a cadre of people that don't learn, don't forget that over time the hobby has become more mainstream and two new generations have come around since the 1990s. Basically, a large number of new faces have entered the scene, and plenty of them have learned to not get baited.
comments.author: @OzixiThrill

comments.text: @andersjjensen It won't take that long for neural processing to be used. It will have the same impact that branch prediction had for CPUs, likely even more so.
comments.author: @Tugela60

comments.text: @strohmy9863 It has nothing to do with game optimization. The tech will be used for rendering prediction, similar to how CPUs use branching prediction to make processing more efficient and hence faster.
comments.author: @Tugela60

comments.text: @s0ulll0warri0r Thank you for the comment, it prompted me to reconsider and use the Carbonaut for CPU IHS instead. After doing a bit of research, it turns out Honeywell PTM 7950 is more effective and reliable than either silicone based paste or carbon thermal pad directly on a GPU die. Phase change material also sidesteps the problems of pump out and dry out that affects silicone-based paste, which is especially an issue for the 6950 XT.

comments.text:
I did a lot of digging around different sources, videos, leaks, forums etc. This is the guessitmate I've got from what everyone is saying:

Raster  (RX 9070 = 100%) 

RTX 4070 Ti (~103-105%)  Sit between here and 4070 Ti Super
RTX 5070 (~110%)  Give or take a bit for the guesstimate
RX 7900 GRE (~110-113%)  Comfortable lead
RX 7900 XT (~100%)  Roughly equivalent give or take a few % 

RT  (RX 9070 = 100%)
It seems to lie somewhere between these cards
RTX 4070 (~105-108%)
RX 7900 GRE (~118-125%) 
RX 7900 XT (~95-98%)

Raster  (RX 9070 XT = 100%) 

RTX 4080/5070 Ti/RX 7900 XTX (~95-98%)  Very close, these perform similarly. 

RT (RX 9070 XT = 100%) 

RX 7900 XTX (~120%)  Improved RT core efficiency looks like it will edge out the old XTX
RTX 4070 Ti (~97-102%)  Most sources seem to place it around here. Sitting between this and a 4070 Ti Super
RTX 5070 Ti (~78-82%)  About -20% in pure RT

Don't forget the pricing :P

comments.text: The 9070xt is just going to be a slightly better in rasterized vs. 5070ti, while having objectively worse features (lower quality frame gen, FSR4 will not be as good as DLSS4, Ray Tracing performance will be a joke yet again). It's also going to consume probably 40W-50W more power on average, so let me ask, what is the point of these cards if they end up costing more than the NVIDIA equivalent after just 1 year of electricity consumption? Their cards are inherently worse technology even if NVIDIA is being a bit disgusting. The price to performance on equivalent cards from both sides is actually just irrelevant when you factor all this in.
comments.author: @tommysalami9896

comments.text: Where did you get the higher power consumption from? Reference design cards are 304w, which is essentially the same as 300w on reference 5070 Ti. Also, how many computers do you need to run to make up $300-400  difference with 4w power savings?
comments.author: @dainiusvysniauskas2049

comments.text: What does any of that have to do with the 5070? And unless you have a 9070xt to benchmark you are speculating.
comments.author: @Prchmnts

comments.text:
@dainiusvysniauskas2049 $300-400? Are you seriously assuming these cards won't be immediately scalped or bought out for AI workloads? You're insane. Also, have you payed an electric bill in the last 5 years? That card would add ~$50 to my electric bill every year. I may have exaggerated the 1 year point, but it's pretty unlikely you'll get this card at MSRP so let's say it takes 3-4 years to make up for the price difference, but you have worse everything? 

My man at gamer's Nexus just showed you in this video that the 5070ti FE (which the 50 series is highly overclockable +300MHz core easily) is consuming 260W-270W total power IN PRACTICE. Not the TDP, the actual power draw. These are two different things. So we can see an ~80W efficiency lead according to AMDs own power benchmark graph they showed us at 4k which is clearly labeled showing 340W for the OC version. There is no FE version of the 9070XT. The OC version, not the stock 9070xt! They haven't beaten NVidia or Intel in power efficiency pretty much ever, or come close, except the recently terrible Core Ultra CPUs, and they have always used significantly more silicon to achieve competitive results with their hardware. 

Let's highlight that the 5080 FE only uses ~290W-~300W in practice according to the GamerNexus chart and it's in a significantly higher performance bracket. You can also overclock this card by +350MHz core and +2000MHz memory as I have, easily to get even more performance at better power efficiency and the power draw would be about the same as the 9070xt apparently. Embarassing. 

Their charts even show that ray tracing performance is worse than the 5070ti, except in the usual games no one cares about like Far Cry 6 and Hitman 3 (they are obviously always using these irrelevent games because they're specifically tailored for AMD hardware). The only chart they showed for rasterized performance is 4k performance, which as of right now only 3% of steam users use according to the steam hardware survey (and I would be hard pressed to believe a majority of them don't use AI upscaling). Why do you think they left out the other charts? You can even see that the performance is hit or miss in the chart they showed. Nvidia did the same thing by only showing a chart for 4k, but they specifically compared it to their own card, not the competitor, so there is a huge difference here. I expect the gap to be even higher at lower resolutions. Don't forget this is the 9070xt OC model vs the stock 5070ti FE.

So let me ask you again, what reason should I buy this card if every feature it has is worse in quality, the drivers are historically worse/less stable, and on average, in games people actually play, the performance is worse when the price over time will be approx the same? We already know these cards will be sold out, scalped, and sold at a premium; that's a no-brainer and I don't think you can argue that. We're going to tout that they had better stock after an entire 2 months of delays because the cards sell out in a couple hours instead of minutes, and it's going to be so stupid. I can't wait.

Why is the 9070xt so behind the 5080 while having a whopping ~8 billion transistors on it (~45bill vs ~53bill? That sounds like terrible engineering and they must be selling these cards at pretty low margins to be competitive. Do you know why that is? Because Nvidia's technology is just better. When we discuss these cards as feats of engineering, AMD is embarassing. If you only factor in the price, then sure this card looks good, I'll give you that. But it's like saying off-brand cola is just as good as coke. It will be scalped anyway though, don't get it twisted. 

Again, Nvidia is being very greasy, but their tech is way ahead, no question about it.

comments.text: Here where I am in Southeast Asia, the general rule of thumb for computer parts shopping is to assume MSRP+50% of MSRP+Other extra charges = Actual Retail Price. This makes a card like the 5090 that supposedly has MSRP of $2000 actually cost $3500~$4000 on store shelves (regardless of stocks). This applies to all tiers of performance. This means a 5070 will likely cost around $800~$900 and sometimes even $1000.

Games that came out recently with RTX-on Control, Alan wake 2, Cyberpunk 2077. I am all for Ray tracing and higher quality moving images. but their charging $899 or more for the worst experience you could have in newer games. more ghosting, input lag, stutters and flickers, artifacting, shimmering, and ghosting again! DLAA shouldn't have been anything more than an A.I. next gen post-proccessing anti-aliasing built and trained on FXAA, MSAA, SSAA, TAA, SMAA, MLAA, TXAA, EQAA, CSAA, and CXAA to identify ghosting or artifacting and then it should remove the blemishes. and I am ok with DLSS for upscaling, but the DLAA in DLSS sucks. this MFG crap is just that crap and i wont be sold on it. I will say the new transformer model is actually really awesome but its celebration is over shadowed by poor price to performance and MFG crap; also any 32 bit game will not run on the 50 series or any new generation of nvidia gpu going forward. so any game that predates fallout 4 and uses a 32-bit engine or specifically the PHYSX 32 bit engine will not run above 7 fps and the card cannot brute force it.

comments.text:
@tomorpedreiro3032 thats kinda a lot less issues than what 50 series has had on its launch, isn't it?
Also having drivers 3 months old means what? Nothing. Except that there hasn't been much need to upgrade them. You know, if it works don't fix it.
That's true that AMD is lacking FSR support in games. And that's true they're behind in RT performance (at least, until tomorrow when 9070 and 9070XT reviews are out).
nVidia was the first company to get anywhere near commonly used RT with their Turing cards. Heck, hence the "R" in "RTX". At first no one really bought it, it was a curious thing to have semi-realtime hardware acceleration for Rays. It had been done before, long, long before by Intel, but it was just like "yea, it can be done but no one cares".

However what I'm expecting from RDNA4 is proper RT performance - maybe, just maybe mid-tier 40-series levels of RT if we are lucky and in some cases slapping around 5070Ti for the XT version. Or at least comparable to, since until now AMD has been like 1 to 2 generations behind in RT - if they are able to get to anywhere near 0,5 generations behind even, it would be a big improvement. And hopefully they can climb up that hill.

comments.text:
@Kirinketsu_ hypr rx is not a gameplay video recording system, it's an optimization to inject amd anti lag and amd fluid motion frames.  relive is AMD's gameplay recording solution and it's quality is comparable to nvidia share.  my personal experience with it is that it's far better because it doesn't constantly fuck up like Nvidia share does.  recordings lacking audio or only being the first frame or freezing during recording, especially with buffered instant replay are super common.  you often hear people say "shadowplay ate the recording". 

you should try using the drivers yourself, they're great.

fsr4 also looks to have closed the gap between fsr and dlss, at least based on the ces footage i saw.

rt is nearly on par with the 40 series, a huge difference from past amd gens,  so a non issue on new cards

nvidia ansel "photo mode" is not supported in most games, only most of the recently released games, which often already have built in photo modes.  reshade already exists and it's easy to find community presets for various games.

The only place amd fails right now is certain creative software, blender, premiere, etc, are a bit slower on amd.

comments.text:
@dan_loeb Forgot what their capturing was called and didnt want to boot up the other PC with AMD GPU in it, Google said Hypr RX.
Some of the RDNA3 cards came with a new encoder, anyways heres some numbers.
RDNA 3 scored 64-AV1, 130-HEVC, 125-H264
RTX 30 scored 137-HEVC, 171-H264
RTX 40 scored 287-AV1, 173-HEVC, 171-H264
RTX 50 scored 331-AV1, 175-HEVC, 340-H264
Intel Arc is like 650 in AV1, which is why some people bought Intel GPUs just for the AV1. 
Nvidia is always updating and working on Encoders, AMD doesnt, every gen of Nvidia card since 20 series had had a newer and better encoder.
RDNA 4 will have updated Encoders, AMD claims up to 25% in H264, up to 50% in AV1, and 11% in HEVC.... thats puts RDNA4 still under the 30 series and nowhere near 40 or 50 series.

I have never had Shadowplay eat a recording, I find it wild that GamerNexus has had so much trouble with it. If something ever does happen with Shadowplay its because of a driver update that disables a setting, or I forgot to reenable something.
I do like the features Relive, but the quality isnt there

PhotoMode is not the same as most ingame captures, and you can enable PhotoMode in a lot of unsupported titles.
Filters are more optimized than ReShades. They are super easy to toggle on and off, wont tank your performance as hard, you can download like 100+ more to use, you can technically add ReShade ones to the folder so you do not have to run ReShade to use filters... also they started RTX Filters which uses even less performance.

RT is not on par with Nvidia... only in light RT workloads and it doesnt seem like thats going to change much with the 9070 

FSR4 might be closer to looking as good as DLSS, but it will only be for RDNA4, and it might be usable on Nvidia RTX cards and Intl later. If you notice in the videos of that demo, it has the same issues FG has when an object passes over another and CyberPunk has with its AA...something DLSS fixes. Maybe they fix that but it seems like that might just be the Ai doing its thing.

As much as people always bash on it, Nvidia has features, and people buy them for those features....this alone is a selling point, hey I am thinking about getting an AMD GPU, what if you want to use RT, your right I should go with Nvidia
comments.author: @Kirinketsu_

comments.text:
@ dunno what yt is doing with my replies, but what does hypr rx have to do with shadowplay (which is called nvidia share now)  hypr rx forces amd antilag and afmf on, and does other latency optimizations in games that dont support fsr or amd anti lag out of the box.

relive is amd's screen recording software built into it's drivers.  and it is far more reliable than nvidia share/shadowplay.  nvidia's solution uses variable framerate recording which routinely breaks, and will completely break a lot of video editors if you use the seperate tracks for game audio and microphone.
